module.title: gender
gnè
module.p: Gender is a property of nouns – every (singular) noun form is either feminine or masculine –

ul.li: Màiri Mary, Nirribhidh Norway, caileag girl and sùil eye are all feminine singular nouns
Dòmhnall Donald, Leòdhas Lewis, balach boy and airgead silver, money are all masculine singular nouns

module.p: Anthroponymic proper nouns are feminine or masculine depending on whether the person referred to is female or male –

ul.li: Some anthroponymic proper nouns are traditionally feminine eg. Ealasaid Elizabeth, Màiri Mary, Raonaid Rachel.
others are traditional masculine eg. Dòmhnall Donald, Seumas James, Tormod Norman.

module.p: Toponymic proper nouns which name countries are always feminine, as are glottonymic proper nouns, eg.

ul.li: Alba Scotland, Nirribhidh Norway, Èirinn Ireland, Sasainn England

module.p: Note that these generalisations also hold for ‘improper nouns’ like An Fhraing France, A’ Ghrèig Greece, An Fhraingis French, A’ Ghreugais Greek.
The gender of common nouns is, strictly speaking, arbitrary. However, there are a number of rules-of-thumb.
The gender of common nouns which describe classes of human and other animals is also usually determined by the sex traditionally associated with the class, eg.

ul.li: feminine – màthair mother, nighean girl, daughter, cailleach old woman, bò cow, cearc hen
masculine – athair father, balach boy, son, bodach old man, tarbh bull, coileach cockerel

module.p: Polysyllabic common nouns with the following endings are usually feminine –

ul.li: -ag eg. caileag girl, piseag kitten, uinneag window
-id eg. càraid couple, drochaid bridge, pitheid parrot, magpie

module.p: But – caraid masc. friend, nàmhaid masc. enemy.
Polysyllabic common nouns with the following endings are usually masculine –

ul.li: -an eg. aran bread, eilean island, òran song

module.p: Common nouns with the following endings which describe people or objects according to job or function are always masculine –

ul.li: -(a)ir eg. clachair stonemason, dorsair doorman, janitor
-(e)adair eg. leughadair reader, seinneadair singer, sgrìobhadair writer, uaireadair watch
